Mr.
Niskanen, you know, when you take a look at President Bush's six years, so far, he really has taken great pride in his tax cuts.
And yet, Democrats and even some Republicans have argued, look this is giving money back to the wrong people.
How do you feel on that issue?
Well, I favor the tax cuts.
But they should've been paired with the spending cuts.
And that's the key problem of the Bush fiscal policy, is that he has cut taxes in three or four occasion and he's had an unusually high rate of growth of federal spending.
So I would favor getting rid of the alternative minimum tax.

I pay a significantly higher tax rate, by the way, under the alternative minimum than I would under the regular income tax, because the deductions that I have do not count against the alternative minimum.
And so the primary people who would gain by eliminating the alternative minimum tax are middle and high-income people and not low-income people.
There would be a loss of federal revenues.
I think something like 20 percent of taxpayers now pay the alternative minimum and that would go up over time.
So there would be a loss of revenues.
And I would favor pairing that with a significant reduction of a variety of federal spending.
What would you cut in terms of spending?
Well, I would cut what is roughly $100 billion of corporate welfare, particular subsidies that affect specific industries and firms.
I would cut what is a huge over-bloated federal subsidies to agriculture.
It is now over $20 billion a year.
I think we will see within the next several years the significantly lower spending for military forces in Iraq and maybe even in Afghanistan.
And I think those are the kinds of measures that ought to be considered in association with getting rid of the alternative minimum.
When you mention words like corporate welfare and agricultural subsidies, you don't sound very much like a Republican.
Well, I think the Republicans in the last few years have forgotten their commitment to fiscal responsibility.
But I think a period in the political wilderness will remind them of their earlier commitment to that end.
And finally, Prof. Spriggs, I'm going to end on you.
Taking all of what we've talked about and bringing it back to the stereotypical American family - of course American families have changed - but mom, dad, a couple of kids.
What do they need to know about the economic policy making that goes on on this larger level?
It affects them greatly.
The federal government can't cause growth but it can cause the shape of growth.
It can cause growth to either favor everyone or to exacerbate inequality.
And over the last four years, we've seen the income of those at the median, the people in the middle, fall while the economy has been expanding.
That's a path that isn't in favor of middle class and working families.
And I think the new policies, the sensitivity to those in the middle and to those at the lower end that you're hearing from this new Congress are going to be good for Americans.
They will finally have a Congress that's paying attention to what's happening to their pocketbooks.
Well, Prof. Spriggs, Mr. Niskanen, thank you so much.

Twenty years ago this summer, Jennifer Warnes, the ballad-belter best known for her ""Up Where We Belong"" duet with Joe Cocker, went in the studio in Los Angeles to cut an entire album of songs by Canadian troubadour Leonard Cohen.

The unlikely collection, called ""Famous Blue Raincoat,"" sold a whopping 800,000 records in 1987 and has just been re-mastered and re-released by Shout Factory with four previously unreleased tracks.
(Soundbite of song ""Famous Blue Raincoat"")
(Singing) It's four in the morning, the end of December, I'm writing you now just to see if you're better...
Cohen, variously referred to as the Godfather of Gloom, or the Grocer of Despair, has always depended on the kindness of female backing vocalists to brighten up his musical palette.
(Soundbite of song ""Joan Of Arc"")
(Singing) Well, I'm glad to hear you talk this way...
In the early '70s, Jennifer Warnes was one of his ever-present chorus of angels.
Leonard's own vocals are earthy and expressive and emitted in a low frequency grumble that begs for upper register decoration.
My voice sounds so much better when a woman is singing with me, Cohen said; some dismal quality is neutralized.
(Soundbite of song ""Joan of Arc"")
(Singing) And who are you, she sternly spoke to the one beneath the smoke...
Jennifer Warnes' take on Leonard Cohen's music is anything but dismal.
In fact, it's sometimes jarring to hear his songs given the high-gloss Los Angeles production treatment.
(Soundbite of song ""Bird On A Wire"")
Studio veterans like guitarist Robin Ford and drummer Vinnie Colaiuta provide the backing and the production by bassist Roscoe Beck is mindful of Joni Mitchell's days with L.A.
Express.
(Soundbite of song, ""Bird on a Wire"")
(Singing) Like a bird on a wire...
Brooding songs like Cohen's ""Bird on a Wire"" sound positively uplifting reframed in this manner and the recording itself is long been prized as an audiophile's dream demo disk.
(Soundbite of song, ""Bird on a Wire"")
I've had the pleasure of meeting Leonard Cohen when we were both on an episode on David Sanborn's ""Night Music"" television show in 1989.
Looking like a more prosperous Ratzo Rizzo, with his hair slicked back and his finely tailored suit, I finally figured out what I wanted to be if I ever grew up.

In the ensuing years, the ever-charming host would invite me over to his pad, ply me with tequila and cranberry juice, a drink of his own invention he called the Red Needle, and played me his new songs.
He even sang a cameo vocal on one of my albums, doing his best Barry White impression on a song called ""Elvis' Rolls Royce.
(Soundbite of song, ""Elvis' Rolls Royce"")
(Singing) It began to sing it, it was the king; it was Elvis' Rolls Royce.
Since those days, appreciating Leonard Cohen has become a bit of a cottage industry, with artists like Elton John and Don Henley lining up to sing his poetic musings on various tribute albums.
But Jennifer Warnes deserves credit for being there first, before Leonard became venerable and certifiably cool; they make a lovely musical couple.
(Soundbite of song, ""Joan of Arc"")
(Singing) I saw her wince, I saw her cry, I saw the glory in her eye...
The album is ""Famous Blue Raincoat""; our reviewer David Was.
